introduction.p: We address the following question: What will happen when you connect a charged capacitor to the ends of a coil as in ?

sidebyside.p: Electrons from the negative plate of the capacitor will start to flow through the coil to the positive plate. The current starts with a maximum value and decreases to zero, but then picks up again, but this time going in the opposite direction. If we assume zero resistance, then current never dies!!

introduction.p: It turns out that back EMF has its maximum value in this circuit precisely when capacitor has fully discharged. Now, due to the back EMF, the capacitor starts to charge again. Since current would be flowing in the reverse direction, previously negatively charged plate will become positively charged and vice-versa.

If the circuit has negligible resistance, very little energy can dissipate. Hence, this back-and-forth charging and discharging of capacitor will continue for ever. We call this phenomenon electromagnetic oscillation. This has analogy to the perpetual motion of a block attached to a spring with inductance serving as mass inertia and 1/capacitance serving as spring constant. Full analogy is summarized in .

We will prove below that current I(t) in an LC-circuit with capacitor fully charged at t=0 and current value positive when flowing into positive plate and negative when flowing away from positive plate is sinusoidal.
I(t) = -\omega\, Q_0\,\sin(\omega\, t),
where
\omega = \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{LC}},
where L is the self-inducatance of the circuit and C capacitance in the circuit. The quantity \omega is angular frequency with which current oscillates. This frequency of an LC circuit is also called the natural frequency of the circuit. The period of oscillation is
T = \dfrac{2\pi}{\omega},
and the cycle frequency is
f = \dfrac{1}{T} = \dfrac{\omega}{2\pi}.

subsection.title: (Calculus) Equation of Motion of LC circuit
subsection.p:
We wish to determine dynamical equation for charge on one of the capacitor plates, say plate G, in the figure. Let q(t) denote the charge on the this plate at time t. We will pick a time t when charge on the plate is positive and is building up. Then, current in the wire connected to this plate will be
I(t) = \dfrac{dq}{dt}.
This current passes through the inductor. Therefore, the back-emf across the inductor will be
\mathcal{E}_L(t) = -L \dfrac{dI}{dt}.
The EMF across the capacitor at this instant will be
\mathcal{E}_C(t) = \dfrac{1}{C}\,q(t).
Now, Faraday's loop rule around the loop of the circuit gives the equation of motion of the charge on plate G.
\dfrac{1}{C}\,q(t) = -L \dfrac{dI}{dt}.
Using Eq. in this equation and rearranging we get the standard form of the equation of motion.
\dfrac{d^2 q}{dt^2 } + \dfrac{1}{LC}\, q = 0.
Taking one more derivative of this equation and using Eq. , you can obtain equation of motion of current in the circuit.
\dfrac{d^2 I}{dt^2 } + \dfrac{1}{LC}\, I = 0.

subsubsection.title: Solution of Equation of Motion
subsubsection.p:
General solution of equation of motion for q, Eq. is a linear combination of sine and cosine functions of t.
q(t) = A\,\cos(\omega\,t) + B\,\sin(\omega\,t),
where
\omega = \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{LC}},
and A and B are constants that depend on initital state of the circuit. With Q_0 as initial charges on the capacitors and I=0 the initial current, we will have
q(t) = Q_0\,\cos(\omega\,t).
Its derivative gives the current as a function of time.
I(t) = -\omega\,Q_0\,\sin(\omega\,t).

subsection.p: Note that Eq. is same as equation of a block attached to spring, the simple harmonic oscillator. Therefore, there is an important analogy between the mechanical system and corresponding electric circuit. displays this analogy.

subsection.title: Energy in an LC-Circuit
subsection.p:
The analogy between the electrical and mechanical systems also extends to the energy in the circuit with the magnetic field energy being analogous to the kinetic energy and the electric field energy to the potential energy. With I current in the circuit and V_C voltage across the capacitor, the net constant in the circuit will be
U_\text{net} = \frac{1}{2}LI^2 + \frac{1}{2}CV_C^2.
In the absence of resistance in the circuit, this energy is conserved over time. Thus, if the circuit in started out with voltage V_0 and zero current, then at time t after closing the circuit, we expect the following from conservation of energy.
\frac{1}{2}LI^2 + \frac{1}{2}CV_C^2 = \frac{1}{2}CV_0^2.
Let t=t_1 when capacitor is discharged fully. At this instant, the voltage across the capacitor will be zero and current in the circuit will be maximum. Let I_\text{max} be current at this instant. Conservation of energy gives
\frac{1}{2}LI_\text{max}^2 = \frac{1}{2}CV_0^2.
We can solve this to find an expression for maximum current in this oscillating circuit.
I_\text{max} = \sqrt{C/L}\,V_0 = \omega\: C\: V_0.
In , I have plotted the energies in the electric field and the magnetic filed for the following values of constants, C=\frac{1}{2}\text{ F}, and L=2\text{ H}, and V_0=1\text{ V}. We see that sum of the energies is constant but at sometime all of the energy is in electric field, at some other time all the energy is in the magnetic field, and the rest of the time the energy is in both fields.

figure.caption: The total energy in an LC circuit oscillates between completely in the electric field between the plates of the oscillator to completely in the magnetic field. The curve with a solid line is the magnetic energy and the one with dashed line the electrical energy. The horizontal line the total energy which does not change with time.

exercise.title: Frequency of Oscillations of an LC-circuit and Voltage at an Instant

statement.p: A 3\text{-F} capacitor is charged so that it contains \pm30 \mu\text{C} on its plates. It is then connected in series to a 2\text{-H} inductor through a switch. The switch is closed at t = 0.
(a) Find the frequency of oscillations of the circuit.
(b) Find the voltage across the capacitor at t = 0.3\text{ sec}.

solution.title: (a)
solution.p:
(a) The frequency f is related to the angular frequency \omega by 2\pi f = \omega. Therefore,
f= \frac{1}{2\pi\sqrt{LC}} = 6.5\times 10^{-2}\ \text{Hz}.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p:
(b) The initial voltage will be related to the initial charge by V_0 = Q_0/C = 10 V. Therefore, the voltage at 0.3 sec will be
V(0.3\ \text{sec}) = (10\ \text{V})\ \cos(2\ \pi\times 0.065\ \text{Hz}\times\ 0.3\ \text{sec}) = 9.9\ \text{V}.

exercise.title: Inductance, Energy, and Current of an LC circuit from Period of Oscillations

statement.p: A 40-\muF capacitor is connected across a 10-V battery till it is fully charged. It is then disconnected and connected across an inductor. The current in the LC circuit so formed oscillated with a period of 5\text{ msec}.
Determine (a) the inductance of the inductor, (b) the total energy of the circuit, and (c) the maximum current in the circuit.

(d) If at some instant, current in the circuit is half of the maximum, what is the amount of charge at that instant on the plate of the capacitor whose charging corresponds to postitive current flowing into that plate?

hint.p: Use the formulas derived in this section

solution.title: (a)
(b)
solution.p:
(b) The total energy in the circuit will be equal to the energy at any time, say at t=0, which is
E(t=0) \amp = \frac{1}{2}CV_0^2 \amp = \frac{1}{2}\times 40\times 10^{-6}\text{F} \times (10\ \text{V})^2 = 2\ \text{mJ}.

solution.title: (c)
(d)
solution.p:
(d) Use conservation of energy for arbitrary time. Writing the energy in the capacitor in terms of the charge on the capacitor instead of the voltage across the capacitor we have
\frac{1}{2}LI(t)^2 + \frac{1}{2C}q(t)^2 = 2\ \text{mJ}\equiv E_{\text{tot}}.
Since current at this time is given to be I = 0.25 A, we can find q at that instant.
q = \sqrt{2 C E_{\text{tot}} - I^2/\omega^2 } = 35\ \mu\text{C}.
